item.title: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film)
item.description:
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film) ðŸ”—

A comprehensive overview of the 1982 American science fiction film produced and directed by Steven Spielberg and written by Melissa Mathison. The film tells the story of a boy, Elliott, who befriends an extraterrestrial stranded on Earth.

Plot ðŸ”—

A race of alien botanists visits Earth, but one of them gets separated from the group and is left behind. The alien takes shelter in a shed belonging to the family of ten-year-old Elliott Taylor. Elliott lures the alien back to his home with Reese’s Pieces, and he hides the creature in his room. Elliott introduces E.T. to his older brother, Michael, and five-year-old sister Gertie, who agree to keep E.T. hidden from their mother, Mary. Elliott and the creature begin to bond, they start to share thoughts and emotions. E.T. displays telekinetic abilities and revives a dead chrysanthemum.

At school, Elliott becomes intoxicated because E.T. is drinking beer and watching television at home. Inspired by a Buck Rogers comic strip, E.T. builds a makeshift device to “phone home”, using various parts around the Taylor home. On Halloween, the children disguise E.T. as a ghost and Elliott sneaks E.T. into the forest, where they set up the device to call E.T.’s people. Elliott begs E.T. to stay on Earth with him, before falling asleep and waking alone in the forest the next day. He returns home to his worried family, while Michael searches for E.T., finding him pale and weakened in a culvert. He takes E.T. home, where Elliott is also growing weaker, and reveal the creature to Mary just before government agents invade and quarantine the house. The lead agent, Keys, asks for Elliott’s help to save E.T., stating that meeting aliens was his childhood dream and he considers E.T’s arrival a genuine miracle. However, E.T. dies while Elliott rapidly recovers. Left alone to say goodbye, Elliott tells E.T. that he loves him, but E.T.’s heart begins to glow and he is revived and restored to health. E.T. tells Elliott that his people are returning for him.

Elliott and Michael flee with E.T. on their bikes, flanked by Michael’s friends who help them evade the pursuing authorities. Heading towards a roadblock, E.T. levitates the boys to safety and lands them in the forest. E.T.’s ship arrives, and he says goodbye to Michael and Gertie, who gifts him the chrysanthemum he previously revived. Elliott tearfully asks E.T. to stay, but E.T. places his glowing finger on Elliott’s head and tells him that he will always be there. The children, Mary, and Keys observe as the ship blasts off into space, leaving a rainbow in the sky.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Dee Wallace as Mary Taylor, the single mother.
  • Henry Thomas as Elliott Taylor, the boy who befriends E.T.
  • Peter Coyote as Keys, the government agent.
  • Robert MacNaughton as Michael Taylor, Elliott’s older brother.
  • Drew Barrymore as Gertie Taylor, Elliott’s younger sister.

Other cast members include K.C. Martel, Sean Frye, C. Thomas Howell, Erika Eleniak, David O’Dell, Richard Swingler, Frank Toth, Robert Barton, Michael Darrell, and Pat Welsh as the voice of E.T.

Production ðŸ”—

Details the development, pre-production, casting, filming, and music of the movie.

Development ðŸ”—

The film’s concept originated from an imaginary friend Steven Spielberg created after his parents’ divorce. He initially planned a darker project called Night Skies but developed a subplot into what became E.T. Melissa Mathison wrote the first draft, titled E.T. and Me.

Pre-production ðŸ”—

Carlo Rambaldi designed the animatronics for E.T., inspired by his painting Women of Delta and the faces of Carl Sandburg, Albert Einstein, and Ernest Hemingway. Kathleen Kennedy visited the Jules Stein Eye Institute to study eyes for E.T. Four heads were created for filming, one as the main animatronic and the others for facial expressions, as well as a costume. Tamara De Treaux, Pat Bilon, and Matthew DeMeritt took turns wearing the costume. Mars, Incorporated refused to allow M&M’s to be used in the film, so The Hershey Company was asked if Reese’s Pieces could be used, and it agreed. Henry Feinberg created E.T.’s communicator device.

Casting ðŸ”—

Spielberg cast Henry Thomas as Elliott after an impressive improvised audition scene. Robert MacNaughton played Michael, and Drew Barrymore was cast as Gertie. Pat Welsh provided the major voice work for E.T., with additional sounds from Debra Winger, Spielberg, and various animals. A scene featuring Harrison Ford as the school principal was cut.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography began on September 8, 1981, in Los Angeles County and the San Fernando Valley, under the cover name A Boy’s Life. Filming locations included Culver City High School, Northridge, Tujunga, Laird International Studios in Culver City, and a redwood forest near Crescent City in Northern California. The exterior Halloween scene and the “flying bicycle” chase scenes were filmed in Porter Ranch. The film was shot in roughly chronological order to achieve convincing emotional performances from the young cast. Sean Frye revealed how the visual effect close-up shots for the climax of the “flying bicycle” chase scene were filmed. BMX riders Robert Cardoza, Greg Maes, and David Lee served as stunt doubles for the scene.

Music ðŸ”—

John Williams composed the score, taking a modernist approach with polytonality and the Lydian mode. Spielberg edited the final chase sequence to suit Williams’ music.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of divorce, alienation, growing up, and communication. Critics have noted parallels between E.T. and Elliott, as well as religious parallels between E.T. and Jesus. Some see the movie as a modern fairy tale, drawing comparisons to Peter Pan and The Wizard of Oz. Kathleen Kennedy highlighted tolerance as an important theme.

Reception ðŸ”—

Details the film’s release, sales, critical response, and accolades.

Release and sales ðŸ”—

E.T. premiered at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival and was released in the United States on June 11, 1982. It opened at number one at the US box office and stayed at the top for six weeks. In 1983, E.T. surpassed Star Wars to become the highest-grossing film of all time. The film was also a merchandising success, with dolls selling 15 million units by September 1982 and becoming the best-selling toy that Christmas season. The film was re-released in 1985 and 2002, earning another $60 million and $68 million respectively. It was re-released in IMAX on August 12, 2022, to commemorate the film’s 40th anniversary.

Home media ðŸ”—

E.T. was released on VHS and LaserDisc on October 27, 1988. The videos were priced with a recommended retail price of $24.95, the lowest initial price at the time for a major movie compared to the normal price of $89.95. The film doubled the record pre-orders of Cinderella released the same month and went on to sell over 15 million VHS units in the United States, and grossed over $250 million in video sales revenue.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The film received near-universal acclaim. Roger Ebert gave it four out of four stars, and Michael Sragow of Rolling Stone called Spielberg “a space age Jean Renoir.” George Will was one of few to pan the film. The film holds a 99% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film was nominated for nine Oscars at the 55th Academy Awards, winning four: Best Original Score, Best Sound, Best Sound Effects Editing, and Best Visual Effects. It also won Golden Globe Awards for Best Picture (Drama) and Best Original Score.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The film has been voted one of the greatest films of all time by the American Film Institute. The line “E.T. phone home” was ranked 15th on AFI’s 100 Years…100 Movie Quotes list. In 1994, it was selected for preservation in the U.S. National Film Registry. In 2023, actress Rita Moreno named E.T. as one of her top five favorite films. Many people in the world of entertainment have cited E.T. as among their favorite films, including filmmakers Stanley Kubrick, Sidney Lumet, Edgar Wright, J. A. Bayona, Dustin Lance Black, Spenser Cohen, Dustin Guy Defa, Gareth Edwards, Michael Giacchino, Sarah Greenwood, Chad Hartigan, Max Hechtman, Jordan Horowitz, Phil Joanou, Travis Knight, David Lowery, Rod Roddenberry, CÃ©line Sciamma, Ed Solomon, Goran Stolevski, Clement Virgo and Molly Manning Walker, actors

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial

item.title: Extra Terrestrial Visitors
item.description:
Extra Terrestrial Visitors ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1983 French-Spanish science fiction film Extra Terrestrial Visitors (also known as Los nuevos extraterrestres and Pod People). It covers the film’s production, plot, cast, release, and reception, including its later cult status due to being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story unfolds in the woods of New England, where egg poachers stumble upon a cave containing alien eggs. After one poacher destroys the eggs, a vengeful alien begins targeting the poachers and a rock band camping nearby. Meanwhile, a young boy named Tommy discovers the remaining egg, which hatches into a creature he names Trumpy. Tommy and Trumpy become friends, and Trumpy develops telekinetic powers. The alien mother searches for her offspring, leading to encounters with the rock band and Tommy’s family. The film culminates in a confrontation between the humans and the alien mother, with tragic consequences for some characters. Tommy and Trumpy say goodbye before Tommy returns to his family.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Ian Serra as Rick, Nina Ferrer as Sharon, Susana Bequer as Lara Stapleton, Sara Palmer as Kathy, Ã“scar MartÃ­n as Tommy Stevens, Maria Albert as Tracy, Emilio Linder as Brian, Concha Cuetos as Molly Stevens, Manuel Pereiro as Bill Stevens, and Frank BraÃ±a as Burt.

Production ðŸ”—

Extra Terrestrial Visitors was a co-production between France and Spain, filmed in Madrid. The cast consisted largely of Spanish actors, and the film was shot in both Spanish and French, later dubbed in post-production. Juan Piquer SimÃ³n directed the film. Faruk Alatan, Dick Randall, and Edward L. Montoro produced the film.

Release ðŸ”—

The film was initially released in France. In the United States, it was sometimes shown on television under the title The Unearthling. Film Ventures International later acquired the film and re-titled it Pod People for U.S. television distribution.

Reception and legacy ðŸ”—

The film received negative reviews, with some finding it unintentionally funny. Its legacy is largely tied to its appearance on Mystery Science Theater 3000 (MST3K), which lampooned the Pod People version of the film.

Mystery Science Theater 3000 ðŸ”—

The film gained popularity after being featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000 in 1991. The MST3K episode used a print of the film re-titled Pod People by Film Ventures International. The opening and ending credits of Pod People are superimposed over footage from The Galaxy Invader. The fictional pop band’s song “Hear the Engines Roll” became a recurring joke on the show.

Home media ðŸ”—

The film has been released on VHS under various titles, including The Unearthling and E. T.: The Second Coming. The MST3K version of the film has been released on DVD and Blu-ray.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra_Terrestrial_Visitors

item.title: The Alien
item.description:
The Alien ðŸ”—

This article details the history of The Alien, an unproduced science fiction film conceived by Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray in the late 1960s. The film was a joint venture between India and the United States, with Columbia Pictures slated to produce it. Despite the involvement of notable actors like Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando, the film was ultimately shelved.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story centers around an alien spaceship that lands in a rural village in Bengal, India. The villagers, awestruck by the craft, begin to worship it. The alien, named “Mr. Ang,” communicates with a young boy named Haba through dreams and engages in playful pranks within the village. The narrative also includes an Indian businessman, a journalist from Calcutta (now Kolkata), and an American engineer. A specific scene is highlighted, describing the alien’s interaction with plant life, showcasing its gentle and curious nature.

Production ðŸ”—

Columbia Pictures was the producer for this planned USâ€“India co-production, and Peter Sellers and Marlon Brando were slated to play lead roles. However, Ray discovered that his script had been copyrighted by Michael Wilson, his representative in Hollywood, who claimed co-writer credit without contributing to the writing. Marlon Brando later left the project, and although James Coburn was considered as a replacement, Ray became discouraged and returned to Calcutta. Columbia Pictures expressed interest in reviving the project in the 1970s and 1980s, but it never materialized.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The article discusses the similarities between The Alien and Steven Spielberg’s E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, released in 1982. Satyajit Ray pointed out the parallels between his script and Spielberg’s film, suggesting that E.T. would not have been possible without his script being available in Hollywood. Spielberg denied these claims. The article also mentions the Hindi film Koi… Mil Gaya, directed by Rakesh Roshan, as another film that appears to be based on The Alien, particularly in its focus on an intellectually disabled person interacting with a friendly alien. In 2003, Satyajit Ray’s son, Sandip Ray, began adapting Ray’s original 1962 story Bankubabur Bandhu into a Bengali television movie of the same name, which was eventually broadcast in India in 2006.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Alien_(unproduced_film)

item.title: The Alien Factor (1978 film)
item.description:
The Alien Factor (1978 film) ðŸ”—

This is a description of the 1978 science fiction horror film The Alien Factor, directed, written, and produced by Don Dohler.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around a spaceship crash in a sparsely populated area of Earth. Three grotesque aliens survive the crash and begin terrorizing the local residents. A character named Ben Zachary steps forward to fight back against the extraterrestrial threat.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Don Leifert as Ben Zachary
  • Tom Griffith as Sheriff Cinder
  • Richard Dyszel as Mayor Wicker
  • Mary Mertens as Edie Martin
  • Richard Geiwitz as Pete
  • George Stover as Steven
  • Eleanor Herman as Mary Jane Carter
  • Anne Frith as Dr. Ruth Sherman

Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino played the aliens Inferbyce and Zagatile, respectively.

Production ðŸ”—

The Alien Factor marked Don Dohler’s directorial debut after he was laid off from his job as a payroll manager. The initial script was a comedy with 15 monsters, but it was changed to a straight horror film with only three monsters. Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino built the creature suits for the Inferbyce and Zagtile, respectively. Ernest D. Farino created the Leemoid through stop motion animation. Filming took place in and around Baltimore, Maryland, from October 1976 to April 1977.

Release ðŸ”—

The film was released on DVD by Retromedia Entertainment on February 26, 2002. Image Entertainment released it on November 15, 2005, as part of the Don Dohler Collection. Mill Creek Entertainment released it on July 19, 2011.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received generally negative reviews. TV Guide gave it two out of five stars, calling it “silly.” Dave Sindelar criticized the acting and direction. Critical Outcast acknowledged the film’s flaws but admired Dohler’s initiative. VideoHound’s Golden Movie Retriever awarded it one and a half out of four bones, noting the decent special effects.

Sequels ðŸ”—

The Alien Factor 2: Alien Rampage was not a direct sequel. Fred Olen Ray, the Retromedia distributor, used the sequel-sounding title for marketing purposes. The original title was Alien Rampage, filmed in 1999 as Don Dohler’s comeback movie after an 11-year hiatus.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Alien_Factor

item.title: Alien Terminator (1988 film)
item.description:
Alien Terminator (1988 film) ðŸ”—

This article details the 1988 Italian film Alien Terminator, also known as Top Line. It distinguishes it from the 1995 film of the same name.

Top Line ðŸ”—

This section provides the original Italian title of the film, which is Top Line.

Film Details ðŸ”—

This section presents key information about the film in a table format:

  • Director: Nello Rossati (also credited as Ted Archer)
  • Writers: Roberto Gianviti and Nello Rossati
  • Stars: Franco Nero and George Kennedy
  • Cinematography: Mario DiLeo
  • Editor: Adalberto Ceccarelli
  • Music: Maurizio Dami
  • Release Date: 1988
  • Country: Italy
  • Language: Italian

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot revolves around Ted Angelo, an alcoholic writer who discovers a 16th-century Spanish ship inside a mountain cave in Cartagena, Colombia. He learns the cave is actually the inside of a crashed UFO. He is pursued by hitmen, a Nazi fugitive named Heinrich Holzmann, and CIA operatives. He teams up with art historian June and eventually involves his ex-wife Maureen. Maureen is revealed to be an alien who has been disguising herself as a human and manipulating world events. She is killed by June. Ted and June go into hiding with an indigenous tribe, where Ted continues to write about his experiences.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the main actors and their respective roles in the film:

  • Franco Nero as Ted Angelo
  • George Kennedy as Heinrich Holzmann
  • Deborah Moore (credited as Deborah Barrymore) as June
  • Mary Stavin as Maureen De Havilland
  • William Berger as Alonso Kintero
  • Shirley Hernandez as Juanita
  • Larry Dolgin
  • Robert Redcross

Release ðŸ”—

This section details the film’s release information. It was released theatrically in Germany on September 22, 1988. It was released on Region 1 DVD on May 25, 2004. It is also available for streaming on platforms like Amazon.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes critical reception of the film. Sci-Fi 100 noted the initial lack of science fiction elements but found the last 30 minutes more engaging. Film Authority described the film as a mix of Romancing the Stone, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and The Terminator.

See also ðŸ”—

This section lists a related film:

  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)
  • List of Italian films of 1988

References ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of citations used in the article, including books, websites, and databases.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the film’s IMDb page.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Terminator_(1988_film)

item.title: Joe Alien
item.description:
Joe Alien ðŸ”—

Joe Alien is a British comic book character who appeared in strips published by Fleetway Publications. He debuted in the preview issue of the science fiction anthology Wildcat in October 1988. The character’s strip was one of four linked serials in Wildcat and was later briefly featured in Eagle after Wildcat was canceled. Joe Alien is the last survivor of the planet Xgangbe-4 and joins the Wildcat mission to help humanity find a new home, commanding the Wildcat 2 exploration shuttle.

Creation ðŸ”—

Barrie Tomlinson created Joe Alien as part of a new science fiction anthology, Wildcat, for Fleetway Publications. The concept involved linking all five features in the comic to form an overall narrative centered on the spaceship Wildcat. Tomlinson created four lead characters, including Joe Alien, to head exploration teams. Massimo Belardinelli was the initial artist for “Joe Alien,” with Tomlinson praising his ability to bring the story to life.

Publishing history ðŸ”—

Wildcat began publication in October 1988, featuring “Joe Alien” as the color strip. Ron Smith took over as the artist from the third issue. Wildcat was canceled after 12 issues and merged with Eagle in March 1989. “Joe Alien” continued in Eagle for four weeks in May 1989 to complete the story arc and also featured in three episodes of “The Wildcat Complete” anthology. Rebellion Developments purchased the rights to Wildcat in 2016 and announced plans to reprint the contents in collected editions. As of 2025, only “Turbo Jones” and “Loner” have been released.

Plot summary ðŸ”—

Joe Alien joins the Wildcat mission after Turbo Jones realizes Earth is doomed. Joe, the last survivor of Xgangbe-4, possesses vast knowledge stored in an external brain-pack. He is selected for his intelligence and physical attributes. After the Wildcat launches, Joe’s sensors locate a potential new home for the refugees.

He leads the Wildcat Two shuttle to scout Area 17, where his team encounters carnivorous vegetation and a two-headed alien. They discover that the plants are controlled by a mad human astronaut from a 2079 Mars mission, who is now worshipped as a god. Joe brokers an alliance with giant insects to escape and later participates in other expeditions.

Joe shares the story of the Xgangbe’s destruction by the Kargroz and his revenge. He is later chosen to find an alien shapeshifter on board the Wildcat. Joe, along with Jones, Loner, and Magee, is kidnapped by a Gamemaster of the Glarzon race but is released after defeating the Glarzon’s troops.

Reception ðŸ”—

Graham Kibble-White described Joe Alien as “dopily designed.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Alien
